results.title: Testing vision in the pre-school child
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Child development series”.
A child’s visual competence includes not only visual acuity but also his ability to attach meaning to what he sees. The tests begin at six months and various procedures are demonstrated with children at 2 1/4, 3 1/2, 4 1/2, 5 and 6 years

results.title: Inert(?) gas compounds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
The first synthesis of krypton difluoride is traced from its inspiration to the first tentative success. Krypton difluoride is prepared by photolysis of fluorine in solid krypton at the temperature of liquid hydrogen and identified by its infrared spectrum.

results.title: Small is beautiful
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, Barrie Howells, Douglas Kiefer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
Up to age forty-five, Fritz Schumacher, economist, technologist and lecturer, was dedicated to economic growth. Then he came to believe that the modern technological explosion had grown out of all proportion to human need. Author of Small Is Beautiful - A Study of Economics as if People Mattered and founder of the London-based Intermediate Technology Development Group, he championed the cause of “appropriate” technology. The film brings us into contact with this gentle revolutionary a few months before his death.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Brittain, Barrie Howells, Douglas Kiefer and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Shapes and polarities of molecules
results.creator_credit: National Science Foundation and Norman Wright Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Observations of electrical effects lead to the concept of molecular polarity. Covalent substances give two types of results: some show marked interactions with electric charges, others give little effect. A model is developed based on polar and non-polar molecules. The molecular dipole model is extended to explain differences in solubility, conductivity and chemical reactivity.

results.title: Co-op housing: the best move we ever made
results.creator_credit: Laura Sky, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
The film explores the dimensions of the housing crisis in Canada, the definition of cooperative housing, and its possibilities as described by some of the people who are living in such dwellings today. Here, housing is owned and operated by people as users, not as investors. The film emphasizes an alternative in housing: security of tenure and mutual aid as the owner-families have come to value them.

results.title: Acid base indicators
results.creator_credit: David W. Ridgway, University of California, Los Angeles and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Proton donor-acceptor theory is used to interpret the experimental behaviour of acid-base indicators. Experiments and animation show the effects on indicators of changing acidity. Equilibrium constants of four indicators are determined and the indicators arranged in order of decreasing acid strength. The competition among bases for protons is shown by mixing the indicators and showing that each changes colour at different total acidity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David W. Ridgway, University of California, Los Angeles and Wexler Film Productions

results.title: Children's play
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Child development series”.
Play is a dynamic factor in a child’s development as well as a requirement for good health. This film points out the changing form of children’s recreations, portraying play at each age level. The film demonstrates the important contributions parents can and should make to give their children the best possible chance for healthy play.

results.title: La-haut sur ces montagnes. C'est l'aviron.
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Jean Palardy and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chants populaires”.
Animated interpretation of two French folk songs. Featuring Madeleine Lachance and the Quatuor Alouette. ‘La-haut sur ces montagnes’ (2.59 mins) is set on the island of Orleans near Quebec, where traditional dances and folksongs are kept alive by the peasant community. In ‘C’est l’aviron’ (3.15 mins) McLaren used gouache drawings which he superimposed against a scenic background to give the impression of a boat travelling along a lake and river which he acheived by zooming during the photographic process.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman McLaren, Jean Palardy and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Challenge for change
results.creator_credit: Bill Reid and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 102 of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
‘Challenge for change’ is a community based government program. Its objective is to shed light on social problems through the production of films. What is Challenge for Change? What happens with children from deprived areas when they are given a free hand to make their own films? Who can be a better voice for Indian needs and aspirations than an Indian film crew? How angry are the black people with the way society treats them? How do government representatives react to social change and the role of the Challenge for Change program? Can a film project serve as a cohesive agent and catalyst for change within a community, and at the same time serve as a means of communication with government? What is community organizing? What role can film play in participatory democracy? Does controversy lead to violence? How useful are the films from Challenge for Change going to be? This film has some of the answers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Reid and National Film Board of Canada
